metadata.title: Experimental study on thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol containing hybrid nano-additives and development of a new correlation

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Thermal Engineering
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /apthermeng
Research Paper
Experimental study on thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol containing hybrid nano-additives and development of a new correlation
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.applthermaleng.2016.09.024 1359-4311/ 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
E-mail addresses: masoud.afrand@pmc.iaun.ac.ir, masoud_afrand@yahoo.com
Masoud Afrand Department of Mechanical Engineering, Najafabad Branch, Islamic Azad University, Najafabad, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
Experimental study on thermal conductivity of MgO-FMWCNTs/EG hybrid nanofluid. Performing tests in temperature range of 25–50 C and concentration range of 0–0.6%. Maximum enhancement of thermal conductivity of nanofluid is 21.3%. Proposing a new correlation to predict the thermal conductivity of the nanofluid.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 1 April 2016 Revised 12 August 2016 Accepted 7 September 2016 Available online 8 September 2016
Keywords: Thermal conductivity Hybrid nano-additives Ethylene glycol New correlation
a b s t r a c t
In this paper, an experimental investigation on the effects of hybrid nano-additives, composed of magnesium oxide (MgO) and functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (FMWCNTs), on the thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol (EG) is presented. The experiments performed at temperatures ranging from 25 C to 50 C and the solid volume fraction range of 0–0.6%. The measurements revealed that the thermal conductivity of nanofluids significantly enhances with an increase in the percentage of the solid volume fraction. Moreover, the thermal conductivity of EG considerably increased with increasing temperature, while thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluid slightly enhanced. The thermal conductivity measurements showed that the maximum enhancement of thermal conductivity of nanofluid is 21.3%, which occurred at solid volume fraction of 0.6% and temperature of 25 C. Finally, efforts were made to provide an accurate correlation for estimating the thermal conductivity at various temperatures and concentrations. Deviation analysis of the thermal conductivity ratio was performed. The comparison between experimental results and correlation outputs showed a good agreement.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ethylene glycol (EG) is an organic complex that is commonly used in numerous engineering applications, such as for antifreeze and other industrial products. The use of EG as a working fluid for convective heat transfer in automobiles, heat exchangers, liquid-cooled computers, fuel cells, HVAC systems, heat pipes, heat pumps, material processing, hybrid-powered engines, solar heating, solar collectors, and systems that work in sub-zero temperatures [1–3]. On the other hand, the thermal conductivity of EG is low, which many researchers have attempted to enhance it. In this way, the researchers found that suspending nanoscale particles into common liquids, called nanofluids, can enhance the thermal conductivity and heat transfer rate [4–12].
A summary of existing experimental studies on the thermal conductivity enhancement of nanofluids is presented in Table 1. The existing experimental studies revealed that the thermal conductivity of nanofluids is a function of the shape and size of nanoparticles, volume fraction of nanoparticles, and thermophysical properties of base fluid and nanoparticles [13–26].
It is obvious that the knowledge of the thermophysical properties of nanofluids is vital for heat transfer applications. Moreover, it is clear that the experimental determining of thermal conductivity of nanofluids is timewasting and costly process. Because of these reasons, many researchers have attempted to present empirical correlations for estimating the thermal conductivity of various nanofluids [27–35]. These correlations were the function of the temperature, solid volume fraction and size of nanoparticles.
In recent decade, there has been interest in using new advanced nanofluids composited of various nanoparticles to enhance the
performance of traditional fluids. This class of nanofluids, which can be prepared by suspending several types (two or more than two) of nano-additives in base fluid, is termed as hybrid nanofluids. Many researches have been experimentally done regarding the properties of these nanofluids. In some of these studies, the combination of oxide and metallic nanoparticles was used as suspending nanoparticles in base fluid. For example, enhanced thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluids such as Al2O3-Cu/water [36], TiO2-Ag/water [37], TiO2–Cu/water [38], and ZnO-TiO2/EG [39] have been reported.
Because of the special thermal properties of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), they have been attached to metal oxide nanoparticles for preparing hybrid nanofluids by some researchers. In this regard, Baghbanzadeh et al. [40] investigated the effect of MWCNT-silica hybrid nanostructures on the thermal conductivity of distilled water. Their results showed that by increasing the concentration of nanoparticles, effective thermal conductivity of nanofluids enhanced. Furthermore, they reported that the hybrid consisting of the higher percentage of MWCNTs showed more increase in effective thermal conductivity of the nanofluid, compared with the other hybrid. Munkhbayar et al. [41] reported a significant enhancement in the thermal conductivity of Ag–MWCNT/water hybrid nanofluid. The measurement results revealed that the maximum thermal conductivity enhancement (14.5% at 40 C) was achieved by a fluid containing ‘0.05 wt% MWCNTs–3 wt% Ag’ composite. Chen et al. [42] investigated the thermal conductivity of Fe2O3-MWCNT/water nanofluid. Their results showed that the thermal conductivity enhancement of water based nanofluid containing 0.05 wt% MWCNTs and 0.02 wt% Fe2O3 nanoparticles was 27.75%, which is higher than that of nanofluid containing 0.2 wt% single Fe2O3 or MWCNTs nanoparticles. Other researchers also experimentally investigated the thermophysical properties of nanofluids containing CNTs and metal oxide hybrid nanoadditives. Some of the studies worth mentioning are the research studies of Nine et al. [43], Abbasi et al. [44] and Syam Sundar et al. [45], Hemmat Esfe et al. [46], Afrand et al. [47,48], and Eshgarf and Afrand [49].
Metal oxide nanoparticles including MgO, TiO2, ZnO, SiO2 and Al2O3 can be easily dispersed in liquids. Among these nanoparticles, MgO nanoparticles also have good thermal properties compared to other mentioned nanoparticles. For example, the thermal conductivity of TiO2, ZnO, SiO2 and Al2O3 are 8.4, 13, 10.4 and 36 W/(m C), while the thermal conductivity of MgO is 48.4 W/(m C), which is higher than that of all of them. On the other hand, CNTs have a high thermal conductivity, low specific gravity, and high aspect ratio as compared to metal oxide nanoparticles. Therefore, the simultaneous use of MgO and CNTs nano-
additives can lead to stable compounds with special thermal properties. The literature survey reveals that there is no research regarding the thermal conductivity of EG based nanofluids containing MgO and CNTs hybrid nano-additives. Hence, in the current research, because of numerous applications of EG in thermal engineering, the thermal conductivity of MgO-FMWCNTs/EG is determined experimentally. Moreover, in order to provide general insights for the thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluids, a comparison of the thermal conductivity ratios of the hybrid nanofluid with EG based mono nanofluids is performed. Finally, due to lack of a model for predicting the thermal conductivity of this hybrid nanofluid, a correlation is proposed using experimental data.
2. Experiments
2.1. Nanofluid preparation
In order to prepare nanofluid, which is the first vital step in the experiments, we must ensure the appropriate dispersion of nanoparticles in the base fluid. In this way, proper mechanisms such as stirring and sonication can be used to achieve the stability of the suspension against nanoparticles sedimentation.
In the current work, ethylene glycol was used as the base fluid. Nano-additives, which are composed of an equal volume of functionalized multi walled carbon nanotubes (FMWCNTs) and MgO nanoparticles, were dispersed into a specified amount of pure ethylene glycol (Merck product, Germany). The chemical and physical data of FMWCNTs, MgO and Merck ethylene glycol are presented in Tables 2–4. X-ray diffraction is used to obtain a characterization of the structural properties of the dry MgO nanoparticles and multi walled carbon nanotubes (Fig. 1).
The hybrid nanofluid samples with solid volume fractions of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.15%, 0.2%, 4% and 0.6% were prepared using a twostep method. The quantity of FMWCNTs and MgO nanoparticles required for various solid volume fractions can be determined using the standard formula [50],
u ¼ m q MWCNTs þ mq MgO
m q
MWCNTs
þ mq MgO þ mq EG
2 64
3 75 100 ð1Þ
where u is the percentage of solid volume fraction, q is the density in kg/m3 and m is the mass in kg. The messes of required nanoadditives were prepared by using a sensitive electronic balance with an accuracy of 1 mg.
In the present experiments, to prepare stable hybrid nanofluid samples, after magnetic stirring for 2 h, the suspensions were exposed to an ultrasonic processor (Hielscher company, Germany) with the power of 400 W and frequency of 24 kHz for 7 h. This method was used in order to break down the agglomeration between the particles, which leads to attain a stable suspension and a uniform dispersion. The photographs of multi walled carbon nanotubes, MgO nanoparticles and the hybrid nanofluid are shown in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Thermal conductivity measurement
sections.text:
In the present study, the thermal conductivity of the hybrid nanofluids was measured by using a KD2 Pro (Decagon Devices, Inc., USA) thermal properties analyser with a maximum error of about 5%. This device employs the transient hot wire (THW) technique to measure the thermal conductivity of nanofluid which is a fast and reliable method. In order to measure the thermal conductivity of the samples, a cylindrical testing chamber with diameter of 30 mm and length of 100 mmwas used. After loading nanofluids into the cylindrical testing chamber, the KD2 Pro KS-1 (stainless steel single needle) sensor, with length of 60 mm and diameter of 1.27 mm was vertically inserted into the center of nanofluids. This sensor has been specially proposed to measure the thermal conductivity of most fluids.
The needle approximates the infinite line heat source. Each measurement cycle is 60 s. Heat is applied for 30 s. Thirty seconds are allowed for temperature equilibration before heating starts. After the reading, the controller computes thermal conductivity
using the change in temperature. The thermal conductivity of fluids can be obtained by the following equation,
k ¼ qðln t2 ln t2Þ 4ðrT2 rT1Þ ð2Þ
where q is the constant heat rate, rT2 and rT1 are the changes in temperature at times t1 and t2 respectively.
It should be noted that a stable temperature bath was used to stabilize the temperature of the samples. All the measurements of the thermal conductivity were repeated three times, which the average values of repeated measurements were recorded. The interval between two single measurements was 15 min.

sections.heading: 2.3. Validation of measurements
sections.text: Before the measurement of thermal conductivity of nanofluids, the device was calibrated with a standard sample of glycerol offered by Decagon Devices Company. Moreover, in order to make sure of the accuracy of the KD2 pro instrument, a comparison was made between the thermal conductivity of pure water obtained by the KD2 pro at different temperatures and those from ASHRAE handbook [51]. As shown in Fig. 3, the measurements are in good agreement with available thermal conductivity data. It was also found that the differences were <0.8% in the mentioned temperature range.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In the first, the effects of temperature and nano-additives volume fraction on thermal conductivity of MgO-FMWCNTs/EG hybrid nanofluid are investigated. Moreover, a comparison of the thermal conductivity ratios of the hybrid nanofluid with that of EG based mono nanofluids presented by previous works is performed. Then, an accurate experimental correlation for estimating thermal conductivity using experimental data will be suggested. Nanofluids are consisted of ethylene glycol and an equal volume of multi walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and MgO nanoparticles. The measurements were carried out at temperatures ranging from 25 C to 50 C for various suspensions at volume fraction of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.15%, 0.2%, 0.4% and 0.6%. Based on the measurements, the ‘‘thermal conductivity ratio” is defined as the ratio of the thermal conductivity of MgO-FMWCNTs/EG hybrid nanofluid to thermal conductivity of base fluid (EG).

sections.heading: 3.1. Effects of temperature and concentration on thermal conductivity
sections.text:
Fig. 4 demonstrates the variations of nanofluids thermal conductivity versus solid volume fraction at different temperatures. As can be obtained from this figure, the thermal conductivity significantly enhances with an increase in the percentage of the solid volume fraction. A similar trend is observed for each temperature. This trend demonstrates that adding more of nanoparticles improves the thermal conductivity of nanofluids compared to the base fluid (EG). This is due to the fact that the thermal conductivity of solid materials is greater than that of liquids. For example, the
thermal conductivity of MWCNTs and MgO nanoparticles are respectively about 3000 and 50W/(m C), while it is approximately 0.25 W/(m C) for EG. Hence, adding the nano-additives into EG would enhance its thermal conductivity. There are various reasons for thermal conductivity enhancement of EG in the presence of nano-additives such as Brownian motion of nano-additives, formation of complexes of nano-additives and collisions between them, formation of a layer of fluid molecules adjacent the surfaces of the nano-additives, and clustering of nano-additives. Clustering of nano-additives leads to create paths with lower thermal resis-
tance, which would accelerate heat transfer in the fluid. This phenomenon can influence the thermal conductivity of nanofluids. The magnitude of clusters is a function of the dimension of nanoadditives and their solid volume fraction. It should be mentioned that smaller clusters have more substantial effect on thermal conductivity enhancement of nanofluids. In fact, the higher solid volume fraction in the nanofluid leads to the smaller distance between the nano-additives; consequently, the probability of formation of clusters due to van der Waals attraction increases. In other words, heat transfer is dependent on particles surface, and the thermal energy interaction be accomplished at the surface of nano-additives. When the clustering of nano-additives takes place, the effective surface area to volume ratio reduces; as a result, the thermal conductivity of the sample decreases. By inspection of Fig. 4, it is clearly found that at higher solid volume fractions (0.2–0.6%), thermal conductivity enhancement is lower than that at low solid volume fractions (0.05–0.2%). The reason may be related to the fact that at higher solid volume fractions the average dimension of the clusters increases.
Fig. 5 depicts the variations of nanofluids thermal conductivity versus temperature for various nanofluid samples. It can be observed that with an increase in temperature the thermal conductivity enhances generally. The main cause of thermal conductivity enhancing due to the temperature rising can be characterized by Brownian motion and the augment in interactions between the nanoparticles. However, the thermal conductivity of EG considerably increases with increasing temperature, while the thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluid slightly enhances. In fact, when nanoadditives are present in the EG, the formation of nano-clusters takes place. Therefore, Brownian motion is limited due to van der Waals forces; as a result, the effect of temperature becomes lower.
Fig. 6 shows the effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on the thermal conductivity ratio of hybrid nanofluids as a function of solid volume fraction and temperature. It can be observed that the thermal conductivity ratio of nanofluids decreases with rising temperature and enhances with increasing solid volume fraction. The cause of reduction of thermal conductivity ratio due to the temperature rising can be related to the fact that the thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluid slightly enhances with temperature, while the thermal conductivity of EG considerably increases with increasing temperature. The thermal conduc-
tivity measurements show that the maximum enhancement of thermal conductivity of nanofluid is 21.3%, which occurs in a solid volume fraction of 0.6% and temperature of 25 C.

sections.heading: 3.2. Comparison of hybrid nanofluid with mono nanofluids
sections.text:
In order to provide general insights for the thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluids, a comparison between the thermal conductivity ratios of present hybrid nanofluid (MgO-FMWCNTs/EG) and three EG based mono nanofluids (Mg(OH)2/EG, MWCNT/EG and SWCNTs/EG) at room temperature is shown in Fig. 7. This figure indicates that thermal conductivity of nanofluids enhances with increasing volume fraction of nano-materials, and enhancement for the hybrid nanofluid is further. Moreover, it is obvious that the nanofluid containing Mg(OH)2 nanoparticles show the least increase in thermal conductivity ratio. This comparison revealed that, for a given volume fraction, the thermal conductivity ratio of nanofluids containing CNTs is meaningfully higher than that of Mg(OH)2/EG nanofluid. The reason may be related to the high surface to volume ratio and high thermal conductivity of CNTs. For example, the thermal conductivity of MWCNTs, SWCNTs and Mg (OH)2 are about 3000, 6000 and 50 W/(m C) respectively. The specific surface areas (SSA) of CNTs is more than three times that of Mg(OH)2.
In spite of the high thermal conductivity of CNTs, it can be observed that, for a given solid volume fraction the thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluid is more than that of mono nanofluid containing CNTs [20]. In fact, when nanofluids are containing only CNTs the probability of formation of large clusters due to van der Waals forces increases. The large clusters reduce the surface to volume ratio, which leads to a decrease in thermal conductivity ratio. However, when the hybrid nano-additives are added to the base fluid FMWCNTs have been tightly enclosed by MgO nanoparticles. This phenomenon prevents the formation of larger nano-clusters of FMWCNTs; consequently, the thermal conductivity ratio enhances significantly.

sections.heading: 3.3. Proposing new correlation
sections.text:
Following, due to lack of appropriate and trustworthy correlation to predict the thermal conductivity ratio of MgO-FMWCNTs/ EG hybrid nanofluid, a correlation that is based on the experimental findings is suggested. This correlation estimates the thermal conductivity ratio of MgO-FMWCNTs/EG hybrid nanofluid as a power-multiplicative function of the volume fraction and temperature. This correlation has a very high accuracy with R2 = 0.99, and is known as
knf kbf ¼ 0:8341þ 1:1u0:243T 0:289 ð3Þ
where k is the thermal conductivity, T is the temperature of the nanofluid in C and u is the solid volume fraction in %. Moreover, the subscript of nf and bf indicate respectively nanofluid and base fluid. This equation clearly shows the effect of solid volume fraction and temperature on thermal conductivity. Therefore, this empirical correlation can be used for engineering applications with high accuracy.
In order to evaluate the accuracy of the correlation, deviation analysis of the thermal conductivity ratio was performed. The deviation between experimental results and predicted data can be calculated as below:

Fig. 8. Comparison between experimental data and correlation outputs.
Fig. 8 illustrates a comparison between the thermal conductivity ratio obtained by experiments and correlation. This figure also shows the measured margin of deviation according to Eq. (4). It can be observed that the most of the data are near the equality line or on it which is not a significant distance. Moreover, the maximum value of margin of deviation is ±1.2%. This graph indicates the good agreement between the experimental data and correlation outputs.
Because of the importance of accuracy in estimating of the thermal conductivity, comparisons between experimental data and empirical correlation outputs at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 9. As can be seen, in most measurement data, the points corresponding to the experimental results and correlation overlap each other or show a small deviation. This behavior reveals that the proposed correlation has an acceptable accuracy.

sections.heading: 3.4. Evaluation of increased pumping power caused by nano-additives
sections.text:
In this section, the effects of nano-additives and temperature on the pumping power compared to thermal conductivity are demon-
strated. The experimental data for the viscosity of MgO-MWCNTs/ ethylene glycol hybrid nanofluid, required to calculate the pumping power, have been extracted from recent work [52]. The pumping power for a fluid can be achieved by using the following equation:
Ppumping ¼ Q Dp ð5Þ where Q is the volumetric flow rate and Dp is the pressure drop.
The pressure drop includes the static head (qgh), pressure losses caused by fittings (qKV2/2) and the friction pressure drop as a function of the friction factor and length (2qf V2L/d). By expressing the component pressure losses in terms of the component inlet velocity, the pumping power for a turbulent fluid flow can be calculated from the following equation [53]:
Ppumping ¼ qQ ghþ K V 2 2 þ 2f L d V2
" # ð6Þ
where L, h, d and V are the length, vertical position, diameter and velocity respectively. Moreover, K is the pressure loss coefficient and f is the Fanning friction factor. For a turbulent fluid flow, Fanning friction factor can be achieved by Blasius equation [54] that can be expressed as follows:
f ¼ 0:0791 lnf qnf Vd
!0:25 ð7Þ
in which, q is density and can be calculated by the following equation:
qnf ¼ uqMgO MWCNTs þ ð1 uÞqEG ð8Þ Since that density affected by nano-additives, ‘‘density ratio” should be defined as the ratio of the density of MgO-MWCNTs/ ethylene glycol hybrid nanofluid, calculated from Eq. (8), to density of EG. In order to evaluate of the effects of nano-additives on the pumping power for the oil flow, Fanning friction factor is investigated for comparing between the pumping power in case of nanofluid and that in case of EG. In this way, the ‘‘Fanning friction factor
ratio” is defined as the ratio of the friction factor of the nanofluid, obtained from Eq. (8), to friction factor of EG (see Eq. (9)). This parameter is a measure of the pumping power.
Fanning friction factor ratio ¼ f nf f EG

Comparisons between percentage of increase of thermal conductivity, viscosity, pumping power and density versus solid volume fraction at various temperatures are illustrated in Fig. 10. It can be observed that the percentage of increase of density is very slight. This means that the pumping power is almost independent of density. As seen in this figure, when solid volume fraction is increased up to 0.4%, thermal conductivity, viscosity and pumping power is increased simultaneously; while, thermal conductivity enhancement is much higher than the increase in pumping power.
This indicates favorable conditions for using MgO-MWCNTs/ ethylene glycol hybrid nanofluid that has high thermal conductivity enhancement against slight. For example, at temperature of 30 C, with increasing solid volume fraction up to 0.4%, thermal conductivity, viscosity and pumping power is augmented 15.3%, 20.7% and 4.8% respectively.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present study, the thermal conductivity of MgOFMWCNTs/EG hybrid nanofluid at temperatures ranging from 25 C to 50 C for various suspensions at volume fraction of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.15%, 0.2%, 0.4% and 0.6% have been examined. Experimental results indicated that the thermal conductivity significantly enhances with an increase in the percentage of the solid volume fraction. Moreover, the thermal conductivity of EG increased with increasing temperature considerably, while the thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluid slightly enhanced. Results revealed that at higher solid volume fractions (0.2–0.6%), the thermal conductivity enhancement is lower than that at low solid volume fractions (0.05–0.2%). The thermal conductivity measurements showed that the maximum enhancement of thermal
conductivity of nanofluid is 21.3%, which occurred in a solid volume fraction of 0.6% and temperature of 25 C. Using experimental results, in order to predict the thermal conductivity of MgOFMWCNTs/EG hybrid nanofluids, a correlation has been proposed. Deviation analysis of the thermal conductivity ratio showed that the maximum value of margin of deviation was 1.2%. Comparison between experimental results and the correlation outputs demonstrated that the correlation has a high accuracy. Hence, this correlation can estimate the thermal conductivity of MgO-FMWCNTs/ EG hybrid nanofluids at solid volume fractions ranging from 0.05% to 0.6% for the temperature range of 25–50 C.
Acknowledgement
The author would like to thank the Najafabad Branch, Islamic Azad University, Najafabad, Iran for the support.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, an experimental investigation on the effects of hybrid nano-additives, composed of magnesium oxide (MgO) and functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (FMWCNTs), on the thermal conductivity of ethylene glycol (EG) is presented. The experiments performed at temperatures ranging from 25 C to 50 C and the solid volume fraction range of 0–0.6%. The measurements revealed that the thermal conductivity of nanofluids significantly enhances with an increase in the percentage of the solid volume fraction. Moreover, the thermal conductivity of EG considerably increased with increasing temperature, while thermal conductivity of hybrid nanofluid slightly enhanced. The thermal conductivity measurements showed that the maximum enhancement of thermal conductivity of nanofluid is 21.3%, which occurred at solid volume fraction of 0.6% and temperature of 25 C. Finally, efforts were made to provide an accurate correlation for estimating the thermal conductivity at various temperatures and concentrations. Deviation analysis of the thermal conductivity ratio was performed. The comparison between experimental results and correlation outputs showed a good agreement. 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
